title: OOXML Structural Analysis: Rust output vs MS Word gold standard
description: Deep comparison of internal .docx structure to identify why Rust output fails to open in MS Word. Files: Broken=/tmp/comparison-result.docx, Gold=/Users/evan/Dropbox/Real Estate Deals/Acquired/115 Industrial Ct/Lease Up/Republic/Lease/msword-comparison-2025-12-28.docx

title: Compare ZIP structure - list all files in both archives
Compare [Content_Types].xml between both files
Compare word/document.xml structure and content
Compare word/styles.xml definitions
Compare word/settings.xml configuration
Compare word/_rels/*.rels relationship files
Compare word/numbering.xml if present
Attempt OOXML validation and report errors
Missing comment range markers (commentRangeStart/End) in document.xml
description:
BROKEN: 0 commentRangeStart / 0 commentRangeEnd elements
GOLD: 8 commentRangeStart / 8 commentRangeEnd elements

Comments exist in comments.xml but lack the inline anchors needed to display them properly in the document body.

FIX: Preserve comment range markers when generating comparison output.

title: Invalid date format in revision elements breaks OOXML validation
description:
BROKEN: w:date="2025-12-29T03:42:39.775744+00:00" (microseconds + offset)
GOLD: w:date="2025-12-28T21:46:00Z" (OOXML compliant)

OOXML spec requires YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ format. The microseconds and +00:00 timezone offset cause Word to reject the file.

FIX: Use chrono to format as %Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ (no microseconds, Z suffix not +00:00)

title: Empty w:del elements placed inside w:rPr (invalid OOXML structure)
description:
**RESEARCH COMPLETE - STRUCTURE IS VALID**

After thorough investigation (OOXML spec, C# reference code, golden files):

The pattern `<w:pPr><w:rPr><w:del .../></w:rPr></w:pPr>` is **VALID OOXML** per ECMA-376 schema.

**Evidence:**
1. OOXML Schema defines `CT_ParaRPr` (rPr inside pPr) as containing `EG_ParaRPrTrackChanges` group which explicitly includes `w:del`
2. C# OpenXmlPowerTools does exactly this at lines 2707-2710 in WmlComparer.cs
3. Golden files (WC-1310, WC-1350) contain this exact pattern

**Purpose:** This structure marks the **paragraph mark** (invisible end-of-paragraph character) as deleted, indicating two paragraphs were merged.

**Conclusion:** The original issue description was INCORRECT. This is not an invalid structure. If Word is rejecting files, the problem is likely:
- Date format issue (separate cell exists for this)
- Some other XML structural problem
- Missing required attributes

**Status:** Closing as INVALID - the structure conforms to OOXML spec.

title: Missing paragraph IDs (w14:paraId, w14:textId) and rsid attributes
description:
BROKEN: <w:p>...</w:p> (no attributes)
GOLD: <w:p w14:paraId="69B80CD5" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00356315" ...>

Missing:
- w14:paraId - paragraph identifier
- w14:textId - text identifier  
- rsidR, rsidRPr, rsidP - revision session IDs

Stats: BROKEN has 2 rsid occurrences vs GOLD's 2,314

FIX: Preserve these attributes from source document paragraphs. Generate valid 8-char hex values for rsid if creating new elements.

title: Run formatting (w:rPr) stripped when wrapping in w:ins/w:del revisions
description:
100% formatting loss when creating revision markup:

| Lost Element | Count |
|--------------|-------|
| w:szCs (font size) | 517 |
| w:b (bold) | 429 |
| w:jc (justify) | 212 |
| w:u (underline) | 200 |
| w:color | 120 |
| w:bCs | 100 |
| w:ind | 62 |
| w:rFonts | 18 |
| TOTAL | 1,715 |

BROKEN: <w:r><w:t>text</w:t></w:r>
GOLD: <w:r><w:rPr><w:b/><w:szCs w:val="24"/></w:rPr><w:t>text</w:t></w:r>

FIX: When wrapping runs in w:ins/w:del, preserve the inner w:rPr formatting from source document.

title: BLOCKER: footnotes.xml missing w:p wrapper around w:pPr
description:
Schema violation causing Word to reject file.

BROKEN:
```xml
<w:footnote w:id="1">
  <w:pPr>  <!-- INVALID: pPr directly inside footnote -->
    <w:pStyle w:val="FootnoteText"/>
  </w:pPr>
  <w:r>...</w:r>
</w:footnote>
```

CORRECT:
```xml
<w:footnote w:id="1">
  <w:p w14:paraId="..." w14:textId="..." w:rsidR="...">
    <w:pPr>
      <w:pStyle w:val="FootnoteText"/>
    </w:pPr>
    <w:r>...</w:r>
  </w:p>
</w:footnote>
```

OOXML schema requires: w:footnote → w:p → w:pPr

FIX: Ensure footnote content is always wrapped in w:p element during serialization.

title: Comments missing w:annotationRef element and CommentReference style
description:
Our comments are missing required child elements:
- w:annotationRef: 0 (GOLD has 8)
- w:rStyle="CommentReference": 0 (GOLD has 8)
- w:pStyle="CommentText": 0 (GOLD has 3)

FIX: Add annotationRef element as first child of comment content runs. Apply proper styles.

title: Content incorrectly routed to footnotes.xml instead of document.xml
description:
Size discrepancy suggests content routing issue:

document.xml: BROKEN=194KB, GOLD=377KB (49% of expected size)
footnotes.xml: BROKEN=55KB, GOLD=3.5KB (15.8x larger than expected)

The ~183KB missing from document.xml may be incorrectly going to footnotes.xml.

FIX: Investigate comparison logic to ensure content is routed to correct XML part.

title: Missing style references (pStyle/rStyle) in document.xml content
description:
BROKEN: 0 style references in document.xml
GOLD: 6 style references (CommentReference, DeltaViewInsertion, FootnoteReference, Hyperlink, Legal3, StyleHeading211ptChar)

Also missing:
- 357 empty <w:rPr/> elements in BROKEN vs 1 in GOLD
- No pStyle elements to link paragraphs to defined styles

The styles.xml is correct, but document.xml isn't referencing the styles.

FIX: Preserve pStyle and rStyle references when generating comparison output.

title: Missing w16du:dateUtc attribute on revision elements
description:
Our output has 0 w16du:dateUtc attributes, GOLD has 359.

BROKEN: <w:ins w:author="Redline" w:id="2" w:date="2025-12-29T04:13:54Z">
GOLD: <w:ins w:id="1" w:author="..." w:date="..." w16du:dateUtc="2025-12-29T02:46:00Z">

Modern Word expects w16du:dateUtc for proper timezone handling.

FIX: Add w16du:dateUtc attribute with UTC timestamp to all w:ins and w:del elements.

title: Fix missing text content and paragraph wrapping in WML comparison
description: Debug why text content (w:t elements) is being lost during comparison. Gold standard has 2625 w:t elements but our output only has 856. Runs are created but empty.

title: Trace atom_list creation to understand ContentElement to XML conversion
Investigate coalesce.rs text generation - find where w:t elements should be created
Investigate C# reference implementation for text content handling in WmlComparer
Implement fix for missing text content based on investigation findings
description:
ROOT CAUSE IDENTIFIED: Text atoms missing "t" in ancestor chain.

**The Bug:**
- Text atoms have ancestors `[body, p, r]` but should have `[body, p, r, t]`
- `coalesce_recurse` groups by ancestor at each level
- Since "t" is missing, `reconstruct_text_elements` is NEVER called
- Result: Empty runs without text content

**The Fix:**
In `atom_list.rs`, when creating Text atoms, ensure the "t" element is included in the ancestor chain. Look at how paragraph atoms include the paragraph in their chain (the recent debug code shows: `ancestors.insert(0, build_ancestor_info_for_node(doc, node))`).

**C# Reference:**
- C# Line 5406 extracts text: `gc.Select(gce => gce.ContentElement.Value).StringConcatenate()`
- Atoms with ContentElement containing characters get concatenated into `<w:t>text</w:t>`

**Expected Result:**
After fix, running comparison should produce runs with text content, matching gold standard's 2625 w:t elements.

title: Run structure incorrectly merged/collapsed during comparison
description:
Example from paragraph 3:
- BROKEN: 3 runs
- GOLD: 43 runs

Runs are being incorrectly merged, losing granular formatting boundaries. Each run in the source document has specific formatting that should be preserved.

Also causing inflated revision count:
- w:ins: BROKEN=637 vs GOLD=285 (2.2x more)
- w:del: BROKEN=160 vs GOLD=71 (2.3x more)

FIX: Preserve original run boundaries when generating comparison. Don't merge adjacent runs even if they have same revision author.

title: Fix run merging and revision fragmentation in WML comparison
description:
Address two related issues in WML document comparison:
1. Run over-merging: 43 runs → 3 runs (losing original formatting boundaries)
2. Revision over-fragmentation: 285 w:ins → 637 w:ins (2.2x inflation)

Root cause: UNID-based grouping in group_adjacent_by_correlation_ranges creates artificial boundaries while losing original run structure from source documents.

title: Investigate run boundary loss: analyze why 43 runs become 3
Investigate revision fragmentation: analyze why 285 w:ins becomes 637
Implement fix for run boundary preservation
description:
INVESTIGATION FINDINGS:
Root cause: Empty UNIDs cause grouping key to be "|{status}" for all atoms.

FIX REQUIRED:
1. In comparer.rs, verify assign_unid_to_all_elements is called BEFORE atom creation
2. Check preprocessing flow: is it called for both documents?
3. Look at compare_part_content - does it call preprocess_markup which calls assign_unid_to_all_elements?

ALTERNATIVE FIX (if UNIDs are being assigned but lost):
In coalesce.rs group_adjacent_by_correlation_ranges, add fallback for empty UNIDs:
- If ancestor_unid is empty, use atom index or original node_id as synthetic UNID
- This preserves run boundaries even when UNIDs are missing

title: Implement fix for revision coalescing
description:
INVESTIGATION FINDINGS:
Root cause: Grouping key at line 1654/1657 is "{unid}|{status}" - different source runs create separate groups.

FIX REQUIRED in coalesce.rs group_adjacent_by_correlation_ranges (lines 1641-1658):
For Inserted/Deleted correlation status, EXCLUDE ancestor_unid from grouping key:

Change from:
  format!("{}|{}", ancestor_unid, status_str)

To:
  if status == Inserted || status == Deleted {
    format!("{}|SIG:{}", status_str, formatting_signature)  // No UNID
  } else {
    format!("{}|{}", ancestor_unid, status_str)  // Keep UNID for Equal
  }

RATIONALE:
- Insertions/deletions don't need to preserve source run boundaries
- They should form continuous revision blocks
- Equal content needs UNIDs to maintain source structure

title: Verify fix against gold standard comparison
Investigate remaining w:t gap to gold standard (1658 vs 2625)
description:
After fixes for text content and revision fragmentation, there's still a gap:

Current state:
- w:t: 1658 (gold: 2625) - ~967 missing text elements
- w:ins: 406 (gold: 285) - still 1.4x more insertions
- w:del: 28 (gold: 71) - now BELOW gold, possible over-coalescing

Investigation areas:
1. Check if text is missing from specific document parts (footnotes, headers, comments)
2. Verify w:del isn't being over-coalesced (28 vs gold 71)
3. Investigate remaining w:ins inflation (406 vs 285)
4. Check if some runs are still being incorrectly merged despite UNID fix

Test command:
./target/release/redline compare \
  --source1 "/Users/evan/Dropbox/Real Estate Deals/Acquired/115 Industrial Ct/Lease Up/Republic/Lease/Version 20699_2 Lease (11-19-25) - LL 1.11.docx" \
  --source2 "/Users/evan/Dropbox/Real Estate Deals/Acquired/115 Industrial Ct/Lease Up/Republic/Lease/Lease (BFI Rev 12-11-25).docx" \
  --output /tmp/comparison-result.docx
